status.description: The issue is open and ready for the assignee to start work on it.
status.name: Open

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

fields.description:
When building the Flight unit tests, I get the following error:
{code}
[16/25] Linking CXX executable debug/flight-test-integration-server
FAILED: debug/flight-test-integration-server 
[... snip long linker command line ...]
/usr/bin/ld: /home/antoine/miniconda3/envs/pyarrow/lib/libgrpc++.so.1.44.0: undefined reference to `std::__throw_bad_array_new_length()@GLIBCXX_3.4.29'
clang: error: linker command failed with exit code 1 (use -v to see invocation)
{code}

This is using a pre-built gRPC from conda-forge ({{grpc-cpp 1.44.0 h3d78c48_1}}).
Other possibly relevant options: {{CMAKE_CXX_STANDARD=17}}, {{ARROW_BUILD_STATIC=OFF}}.
fields.summary: [C++] Linker error when building Flight tests

comments.body: cc [~uwe] does this error ring a bell?

I wasn't able to reproduce with the same version of gRPC, but I recall occasionally seeing issues like this when my environment had too old a version of sysroot_linux-64 from conda-forge (my env has {{2.12 he073ed8_15}} for what it's worth)
Hmm, I don't even have a "sysroot_linux-64" in my environment. Do you know where it comes from? Should I install the "compilers" package perhaps?

Wow, trying to use the "compilers" and "clang" conda packages completely breaks the build here :
{code}
/home/antoine/miniconda3/envs/pyarrow/bin/ld: warning: libbz2.so.1.0, needed by debug/libarrow.so.800.0.0, not found (try using -rpath or -rpath-link)
/home/antoine/miniconda3/envs/pyarrow/bin/ld: warning: liblz4.so.1, needed by debug/libarrow.so.800.0.0, not found (try using -rpath or -rpath-link)
/home/antoine/miniconda3/envs/pyarrow/bin/ld: warning: libsnappy.so.1, needed by debug/libarrow.so.800.0.0, not found (try using -rpath or -rpath-link)
/home/antoine/miniconda3/envs/pyarrow/bin/ld: warning: libzstd.so.1, needed by debug/libarrow.so.800.0.0, not found (try using -rpath or -rpath-link)
/home/antoine/miniconda3/envs/pyarrow/bin/ld: debug/libarrow.so.800.0.0: undefined reference to `snappy::MaxCompressedLength(unsigned long)'
[...]
{code}

Odd, if you don't have it in the first place, then maybe it's not necessary. I'm not sure where it comes from (likely compilers?)

I just tried again without compilers, though, and it still worked fine.
Which distro version are you on? I'm using Ubuntu 20.04 and trying to build with clang-10.
Ah, I'm on Ubuntu 18.04…let me try in a Docker container
Looking at the error message again, GLIBCXX_3.4.29 isn't provided by the libstdc++ on Ubuntu 20.04. It seems like conda-forge is linking against an extremely recent version of libstdc++.

Hmm, setting LDFLAGS seems to improve things a bit but I get another error :-(

{code}
/home/antoine/miniconda3/envs/pyarrow/bin/ld: /home/antoine/miniconda3/envs/pyarrow/lib/libcrypto.so: undefined reference to `clock_gettime@GLIBC_2.17'
/home/antoine/miniconda3/envs/pyarrow/bin/ld: /home/antoine/miniconda3/envs/pyarrow/lib/libcrypto.so: undefined reference to `__fdelt_chk@GLIBC_2.15'
/home/antoine/miniconda3/envs/pyarrow/bin/ld: /home/antoine/miniconda3/envs/pyarrow/lib/libcrypto.so: undefined reference to `memcpy@GLIBC_2.14'
/home/antoine/miniconda3/envs/pyarrow/bin/ld: /home/antoine/miniconda3/envs/pyarrow/lib/libcrypto.so: undefined reference to `getauxval@GLIBC_2.16'
/home/antoine/miniconda3/envs/pyarrow/bin/ld: /home/antoine/miniconda3/envs/pyarrow/lib/libcrypto.so: undefined reference to `secure_getenv@GLIBC_2.17'
{code}

(a frankly weird one I might say)

Ah! Activating the environment again seems to have fixed the issue (perhaps some packages set some custom environment variables when they are being activated? a pity no messages says so when installing them...).

…that seems quite odd indeed.

I can reproduce your original issue in a Ubuntu 20.04 container, at least. FYI: 

{noformat}
# ldd /root/miniconda3/envs/dev/lib/libgrpc++.so.1.44.0 | grep libstdc
	libstdc++.so.6 => /root/miniconda3/envs/dev/lib/./libstdc++.so.6 (0x00007fe181f8a000)
{noformat}

Adding this library to the link command also fixes things.

The error is exactly as you discovered: conda-forge uses a more recent libstdc++ than your system. Reactivating your environment loads the correct environment variables. This should also happen automatically if you install packages with {{conda}} or a recent {{mamba}} version.
The environment variables are typically set by packages that end in the platform, e.g. `gxx_linux-64`.
Not a Arrow issue anymore, but is it possible for conda to display a message when a newly installed package defines environment variables?

Not that easily but nowadays the {{conda}} and {{mamba}} commands are no longer executables but shell functions to exactly handle the reactivation of the environment on installation of these packages.
